description: In this series, Sean and Mike explore several tools that are commonly used for Penetration Testing. They show how the tools work, and explore their functionality. They also demonstrate how to create your own tools, like loading Kali Nethunter on a Nexus 7 and creating your own PwnPad.
name: Security Tech Skills
subtitle: Commonly used penetration tools

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike take a look at Kali 2.0. They talk about the major changes from Kali 1.0, and explore the new interface. They also talk about the different versions available, and the new update model.
episodes.title: Introducing Kali 2.0
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.012 --> 00:00:03.059
[SOUND]

2
00:00:03.059 --> 00:00:09.973
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:09.973 --> 00:00:12.640
Hello and
welcome to another episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.640 --> 00:00:14.330
I'm your host Mike Rodrick.

5
00:00:14.330 --> 00:00:17.150
With me today is the famous Sean Oriyano.

6
00:00:17.150 --> 00:00:20.090
And in this episode Sean
we're going to be covering

7
00:00:20.090 --> 00:00:24.970
Kali which is something we've got some
other episodes on but this is Kali 2.0.

8
00:00:24.970 --> 00:00:26.400
Some big changes and

9
00:00:26.400 --> 00:00:29.320
a lot of stuff that we really need
to take a look at, right Sean?

10
00:00:29.320 --> 00:00:31.020
>> Yeah, absolutely.

11
00:00:31.020 --> 00:00:35.252
You know, as Mike said,
we have talked about Kali

12
00:00:35.252 --> 00:00:40.220
before and it's been around for a while.

13
00:00:40.220 --> 00:00:42.900
And so
it wasn't actually all that long ago,

14
00:00:42.900 --> 00:00:47.050
a couple months ago we just got
finished talking about 1.0.

15
00:00:47.050 --> 00:00:51.145
So what we're doing now of course,
we're talking about 2.0.

16
00:00:51.145 --> 00:00:56.660
2.0 was released the middle of August,
August eleventh to be specific.

17
00:00:56.660 --> 00:01:02.300
And some of you may have gotten
ahold of it at that point in time.

18
00:01:02.300 --> 00:01:06.170
That's actually a good feat if you did,
because it was, the offensive security

19
00:01:06.170 --> 00:01:10.820
site was really beaten up that day
because it was such a big deal.

20
00:01:10.820 --> 00:01:13.990
This was actually debuted at DEF CON.

21
00:01:13.990 --> 00:01:18.500
So, that's why they held off and
held off and held off.

22
00:01:18.500 --> 00:01:23.115
You saw some before the official
announcement at DEF CON, or

23
00:01:23.115 --> 00:01:28.726
official debut at DEF CON, you saw
some images getting bounced around and

24
00:01:28.726 --> 00:01:33.820
stuff like that but the real official
one came out right at DEF CON.

25
00:01:33.820 --> 00:01:38.260
They did some training there and then the
rest of the world started seeing it and

26
00:01:38.260 --> 00:01:40.180
it's still pretty new to most people.

27
00:01:40.180 --> 00:01:44.500
I mean we're barely talking a month that
the thing has been out, so there's a lot

28
00:01:44.500 --> 00:01:49.630
of people out there still learning it and
getting used to this whole new version.

29
00:01:49.630 --> 00:01:53.010
Which it really is, when you look at it,
is a whole new version.

30
00:01:53.010 --> 00:01:56.920
Even though you may not think
that it's anything more than just

31
00:01:56.920 --> 00:02:01.840
an upgrade to the existing one, which is
true, it is an upgrade, but there's so

32
00:02:01.840 --> 00:02:04.190
much more to that that we're
trying to introduce here.

33
00:02:04.190 --> 00:02:09.190
So enough that we're gonna spend some
serious time talking about what makes it

34
00:02:09.190 --> 00:02:14.280
different, some things you can do with it,
and just kind of

35
00:02:14.280 --> 00:02:19.990
get you familiarized with the differences
in this product over the previous one.

36
00:02:19.990 --> 00:02:23.010
Now, that doesn't mean,
even though there's some new stuff, or

37
00:02:23.010 --> 00:02:27.460
a good number of new things in Kali 2.0,
it doesn't mean that you

38
00:02:27.460 --> 00:02:32.280
can't go back to what we had in
the library already for 1.0.

39
00:02:32.280 --> 00:02:35.900
And use a lot of that knowledge, cuz
a lot of those tools have carried over.

40
00:02:35.900 --> 00:02:37.940
But there are some new tools as well, and

41
00:02:37.940 --> 00:02:42.940
we'll focus on those
whenever that comes up.

42
00:02:42.940 --> 00:02:47.290
So that's really kind of what
we're looking at here, and

43
00:02:47.290 --> 00:02:50.250
that's why we're doing this exploration.

44
00:02:50.250 --> 00:02:53.980
So let's just kinda talk about the first
thing, about some of the major things

45
00:02:53.980 --> 00:02:57.240
you're gonna notice with
Kali when you get into it.

46
00:02:57.240 --> 00:03:02.845
They did change the pronunciation of it,
you speak Kali now, it's Kali.

47
00:03:02.845 --> 00:03:06.940
[LAUGH] Just tell her that we
both pronounce it different,

48
00:03:06.940 --> 00:03:10.370
and there's not going to be a compromise.

49
00:03:10.370 --> 00:03:13.450
>> We're going to stick to our guns,
you know.

50
00:03:13.450 --> 00:03:15.378
>> You just choose the one
that's appropriate.

51
00:03:15.378 --> 00:03:20.217
[LAUGH]
Anyway,

52
00:03:20.217 --> 00:03:23.720
so, the major differences we
have between version one and

53
00:03:23.720 --> 00:03:27.620
two, probably the biggest thing people
are gonna notice is the interface.

54
00:03:27.620 --> 00:03:31.960
Interface is definitely different,
and I'll show you that in a bit.

55
00:03:31.960 --> 00:03:33.770
But the interface is different.

56
00:03:33.770 --> 00:03:39.130
It's not as, well it's a lot
cleaner is a better way to put it.

57
00:03:39.130 --> 00:03:44.265
It's a lot cleaner, it's organized
a bit differently over the 1.0 version.

58
00:03:44.265 --> 00:03:50.505
1.0 version if you get down to it, in fact
if you go from Backtrack over to Kali 1.0,

59
00:03:50.505 --> 00:03:55.790
to 2.0, you'll notice that the tools went
more from just being an afterthought

60
00:03:55.790 --> 00:03:58.900
to all of a sudden being part of the menu,
to having their own menu in there.

61
00:03:58.900 --> 00:04:02.550
And if you remember, when we did 1.0,
we went to the menu and

62
00:04:02.550 --> 00:04:06.770
we had to go all the way down
to the normal tools in Linux and

63
00:04:06.770 --> 00:04:11.570
there was a cascading menu that came
out for the penetration testing stuff.

64
00:04:11.570 --> 00:04:14.270
And that opened up into
several different levels.

65
00:04:14.270 --> 00:04:15.470
It's easy to get lost.

66
00:04:15.470 --> 00:04:16.380
When you get down to it.

67
00:04:16.380 --> 00:04:20.830
I mean, there were several times in the
demos here, that even though I knew where

68
00:04:20.830 --> 00:04:26.310
things were in Kali 1.0,
I would go through and find it,

69
00:04:26.310 --> 00:04:30.780
and I'd still have the menus that go and
popping in or snapping back or whatever.

70
00:04:30.780 --> 00:04:34.560
So what they've done is they fixed the
interface, or made it a little cleaner, so

71
00:04:34.560 --> 00:04:36.180
it's much more purpose built.

72
00:04:36.180 --> 00:04:40.420
This really truly is a penetration
testing tool when we go to 2.0.

73
00:04:40.420 --> 00:04:41.950
So that's a great thing.

74
00:04:41.950 --> 00:04:42.520
>> Nice.

75
00:04:42.520 --> 00:04:45.970
>> So, interface is a lot cleaner,
the tools that you would use,

76
00:04:45.970 --> 00:04:49.750
a lot of them are right
there on the surface.

77
00:04:49.750 --> 00:04:52.270
There's quick access menus in here, so and

78
00:04:52.270 --> 00:04:55.320
then there are a lot of other
little details in there.

79
00:04:55.320 --> 00:04:59.920
So, that's the biggest thing that you
are going to notice when you come into it.

80
00:04:59.920 --> 00:05:03.216
Okay, but just having a new
interface that's nothing really.

81
00:05:03.216 --> 00:05:07.620
It is a GNOME based interface by
the way for those of you keeping score.

82
00:05:07.620 --> 00:05:10.150
It is using the interface called GNOME.

83
00:05:10.150 --> 00:05:14.720
GNOME has been around for a while,
as one of the major Linux interfaces.

84
00:05:14.720 --> 00:05:18.020
So it's using GNOME, but it's been really,
really prettied up and cleaned up.

85
00:05:18.020 --> 00:05:19.220
But it looks quite nice.

86
00:05:19.220 --> 00:05:21.525
You know, so that's a big thing.

87
00:05:22.695 --> 00:05:25.805
As far as other changes
that have been done,

88
00:05:25.805 --> 00:05:30.705
this is fully supporting
Debian on the back end.

89
00:05:30.705 --> 00:05:37.675
So, we were using it,
which is a major distro of Linux.

90
00:05:37.675 --> 00:05:40.755
They're using Debian on the back end so

91
00:05:40.755 --> 00:05:45.230
that means that they're really unleashing,
unlocking the power of one of the full

92
00:05:45.230 --> 00:05:49.220
distros instead of going after something
like Ubuntu or something like that.

93
00:05:49.220 --> 00:05:52.720
They just bypassed it and
went right to what's behind Ubuntu and

94
00:05:52.720 --> 00:05:54.430
a lot of the other major ones.

95
00:05:54.430 --> 00:05:58.360
You know, there's some Some
benefits there too by the way,

96
00:05:58.360 --> 00:06:00.993
since Debian is a major distro of Linux.

97
00:06:00.993 --> 00:06:04.691
You've got a situation where there's
a lot of tools out there that

98
00:06:04.691 --> 00:06:08.256
are supported in that, so
it means that you can add on a lot of your

99
00:06:08.256 --> 00:06:11.467
own own tools to Kali to
enhance its functionality.

100
00:06:11.467 --> 00:06:14.242
And you're gonna wanna do that,
you're definitely gonna wanna do that.

101
00:06:14.242 --> 00:06:18.167
And I'm gonna show you
not only how to add tools

102
00:06:18.167 --> 00:06:23.160
into Kali your own, but I'm also going to
show you along the way how to make your

103
00:06:23.160 --> 00:06:25.780
own custom image that
incorporates those tools.

104
00:06:25.780 --> 00:06:29.280
So you're not stuck with just using
what offensive security provides,

105
00:06:29.280 --> 00:06:33.740
I'm also going to show you, hey,
take a base installation of KOE and

106
00:06:33.740 --> 00:06:36.470
install your own tools
into it from where ever.

107
00:06:36.470 --> 00:06:40.700
And then make your own ISO file out of it
which is a really neat ability to have.

108
00:06:41.780 --> 00:06:44.850
So those are some cool things.

109
00:06:44.850 --> 00:06:48.190
And then just one other
thing to mention here.

110
00:06:48.190 --> 00:06:51.080
Just remember we're just
doing the intro here.

111
00:06:51.080 --> 00:06:53.420
This isn't what it's limited to.

112
00:06:53.420 --> 00:06:54.950
Platform support.

113
00:06:54.950 --> 00:06:57.710
Platform support is much more broad,
I would say,

114
00:06:57.710 --> 00:07:00.960
with 2.0 than it was
with the previous one.

115
00:07:00.960 --> 00:07:06.555
2.0 supports a wider range of hardware

116
00:07:07.735 --> 00:07:13.925
than we had available or officially
supported for 1.0, which is really neat.

117
00:07:13.925 --> 00:07:15.905
You can install it in anything from, well,

118
00:07:15.905 --> 00:07:20.865
you could already do Kali 1.0 on
the Raspberry Pi, but you can do 2 on

119
00:07:20.865 --> 00:07:26.065
the Raspberry Pi plus a bunch of other
devices if you so choose to do that.

120
00:07:26.065 --> 00:07:30.060
In fact, I saw somebody which
you'll find out later on.

121
00:07:30.060 --> 00:07:33.870
I can't really find any logic
behind doing it just because,

122
00:07:33.870 --> 00:07:37.200
other than just saying that you did it,
which sometimes is enough, right?

123
00:07:37.200 --> 00:07:41.950
>> Right. [LAUGH] >> But
somebody installed Kali like we have here.

124
00:07:43.070 --> 00:07:47.757
They installed Kali right
on to their smart phone.

125
00:07:47.757 --> 00:07:51.426
Unfortunately, no one told them that we
already have a version of Kali designed

126
00:07:51.426 --> 00:07:52.302
for smart phones so

127
00:07:52.302 --> 00:07:55.556
they didn't have to spend a week in
their mom's basement doing that.

128
00:07:55.556 --> 00:07:59.143
[LAUGH] So oops, sorry.

129
00:07:59.143 --> 00:08:02.634
But let me just give you a quick
look at the interface so

130
00:08:02.634 --> 00:08:06.400
you kind of see what
we're talking about here.

131
00:08:06.400 --> 00:08:09.770
Is what I have brought up on my screen for

132
00:08:09.770 --> 00:08:13.410
you is I have Kali and
I have it running in virtual machine.

133
00:08:13.410 --> 00:08:15.390
So, just so you know.

134
00:08:15.390 --> 00:08:18.190
So it's running right
here in virtual machine.

135
00:08:18.190 --> 00:08:21.190
You can see it is a different interface.

136
00:08:21.190 --> 00:08:25.210
It's recognizable to things
you've seen in the past.

137
00:08:25.210 --> 00:08:31.610
This isn't really far removed
from what we had in Kali 1.0.

138
00:08:31.610 --> 00:08:34.400
But it is indeed different.

139
00:08:34.400 --> 00:08:37.660
You know, you can see it's a lot cleaner.

140
00:08:38.750 --> 00:08:41.350
We got the quick access
menus across the top.

141
00:08:41.350 --> 00:08:43.330
You know, the pull downs.

142
00:08:43.330 --> 00:08:46.120
You can see, we've got our other icons.

143
00:08:46.120 --> 00:08:48.280
I'm gonna show you the icons
in the upper right.

144
00:08:48.280 --> 00:08:51.100
There's actually some neat
things roaming around up there.

145
00:08:51.100 --> 00:08:52.610
But first of all,

146
00:08:52.610 --> 00:08:56.160
let me show you about the first part
of it with the applications menu.

147
00:08:56.160 --> 00:08:59.490
When you click on the applications menu,

148
00:08:59.490 --> 00:09:04.280
you'll notice right away that this is
a big deal when you get down to it.

149
00:09:04.280 --> 00:09:07.480
I mean, you look at it,
it's got this menu that just pops open.

150
00:09:07.480 --> 00:09:12.490
I mean take a look it's got everything
organized a lot more nicely for you.

151
00:09:12.490 --> 00:09:16.160
You can just instead of just having to go
through menu after menu after menu and

152
00:09:16.160 --> 00:09:19.120
keep going down to say I
wanted to do PEN testing.

153
00:09:19.120 --> 00:09:21.640
Then I do information gathering,
then I wanna open up this,

154
00:09:21.640 --> 00:09:23.420
then I wanna open up another sub-menu.

155
00:09:23.420 --> 00:09:24.200
You don't have to do that.

156
00:09:24.200 --> 00:09:28.780
And, that was something that I
found kinda irritating before.

157
00:09:28.780 --> 00:09:30.740
It was just, can we get on with it?

158
00:09:30.740 --> 00:09:32.930
You know, do I have to keep fishing and
digging around?

159
00:09:32.930 --> 00:09:34.060
I felt like I was getting a shovel and

160
00:09:34.060 --> 00:09:37.891
just having to keep digging a hole to
China in some cases, to get this stuff.

161
00:09:37.891 --> 00:09:40.206
>> [LAUGH]
>> I wanna get right to what I need to do,

162
00:09:40.206 --> 00:09:42.520
you know,
cuz I've got a thought process going.

163
00:09:42.520 --> 00:09:43.410
Whatever.

164
00:09:43.410 --> 00:09:46.880
So what you can do here is
just open the Applications.

165
00:09:46.880 --> 00:09:50.250
And it's got everything laid out there for
you, okay.

166
00:09:50.250 --> 00:09:52.990
What I do want you to keep in
mind when you're looking at this,

167
00:09:52.990 --> 00:09:57.670
though, is the fact that not
everything that's available

168
00:09:57.670 --> 00:10:00.840
in Kali is something that's
gonna show up on a menu.

169
00:10:00.840 --> 00:10:05.280
Kali has a substantial, there's
several hundred tools in this product.

170
00:10:05.280 --> 00:10:10.250
There's some tools that are strictly
available only at the command line.

171
00:10:10.250 --> 00:10:12.540
And you're gonna have to open
up a terminal window and

172
00:10:12.540 --> 00:10:14.150
actually type the name for the tool.

173
00:10:14.150 --> 00:10:16.190
Okay?
We haven't got there yet, but

174
00:10:16.190 --> 00:10:17.790
I'm just making you aware of that.

175
00:10:17.790 --> 00:10:22.270
Don't think that oh,
this is the extent of what you've got.

176
00:10:22.270 --> 00:10:25.050
No, it just means that they put some
of the more commonly used tools,

177
00:10:25.050 --> 00:10:27.970
they made them accessible to the menus for
you.

178
00:10:27.970 --> 00:10:32.660
And some of these tools that you'll
see on here available on these menus

179
00:10:32.660 --> 00:10:35.160
in fact themselves
are console based tools.

180
00:10:35.160 --> 00:10:38.180
They do not have a GUI, they're
just acting as a quick shortcut for

181
00:10:38.180 --> 00:10:40.450
you to click on and open the thing up.

182
00:10:40.450 --> 00:10:48.240
So, in that case I think that
to me is a big, big benefit.

183
00:10:48.240 --> 00:10:51.160
And you're gonna notice that there are
some new things as I scroll through it,

184
00:10:51.160 --> 00:10:56.340
but we'll talk about
those once we get there.

185
00:10:56.340 --> 00:10:59.310
We'll be talking about some of
those things as we go through.

186
00:10:59.310 --> 00:11:00.850
Won't be going through
every tool in there.

187
00:11:00.850 --> 00:11:02.860
Like I said, this isn't the time for that,

188
00:11:02.860 --> 00:11:08.470
cuz a lot of those tools are still
carryovers from previous versions.

189
00:11:08.470 --> 00:11:13.230
But there are some new ones
that are interesting and

190
00:11:13.230 --> 00:11:14.460
ones I wanna bring to your attention.

191
00:11:14.460 --> 00:11:18.050
And you're gonna have to augment what
we're doing here with some of your own

192
00:11:18.050 --> 00:11:18.734
exploration.

193
00:11:18.734 --> 00:11:21.336
[LAUGH] And trying out.

194
00:11:21.336 --> 00:11:25.040
But that's all well and good for that.

195
00:11:25.040 --> 00:11:29.800
I will tell you something here that's kind
of interesting about this metasploit.

196
00:11:29.800 --> 00:11:34.770
We did a whole series of classes,
you know, Mike and I on metasploit.

197
00:11:34.770 --> 00:11:38.100
Metasploit, you know, you can see that
it has this little shield you know,

198
00:11:38.100 --> 00:11:41.475
icon however saying
the Metasploit framework.

199
00:11:41.475 --> 00:11:45.845
That's just the basic Metasploit product.

200
00:11:45.845 --> 00:11:48.375
If you wanna upgrade for
anything for there, you wanna go

201
00:11:48.375 --> 00:11:52.205
to the higher end versions then you'll
have to actually download them.

202
00:11:52.205 --> 00:11:56.110
The versions that were available in
previous versions, they just said,

203
00:11:56.110 --> 00:11:57.250
we're not including that anymore.

204
00:11:57.250 --> 00:11:58.520
We'll just give you the basic stuff,

205
00:11:58.520 --> 00:12:01.210
if you wanna go up above that,
you're gonna have to go and download it.

206
00:12:01.210 --> 00:12:02.060
Go to Rapid7.

207
00:12:02.060 --> 00:12:04.020
They'll still give it to you, but

208
00:12:04.020 --> 00:12:06.860
you're gonna have to go
there to go get it yourself.

209
00:12:07.940 --> 00:12:11.360
Anyway, so I just pointed out there,

210
00:12:11.360 --> 00:12:14.040
you'll notice I pointed out
something on this left-hand side.

211
00:12:14.040 --> 00:12:17.230
This is your quick launch deal over here.

212
00:12:17.230 --> 00:12:20.170
You'll notice that it already has some
stuff that I have not changed since

213
00:12:20.170 --> 00:12:21.860
installation at all, by the way.

214
00:12:21.860 --> 00:12:26.500
This installation is just stock, so

215
00:12:26.500 --> 00:12:31.650
what I've got is, I have just some of
my more commonly used tools over there.

216
00:12:31.650 --> 00:12:33.550
And I can add to that whenever I want.

217
00:12:33.550 --> 00:12:36.930
In fact, I went in and added my terminal
window in there, or terminal window.

218
00:12:36.930 --> 00:12:40.635
You know, as one of the viewers in
here says, who uses the GUI anyway?

219
00:12:40.635 --> 00:12:42.330
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah, well, you know,

220
00:12:42.330 --> 00:12:43.180
we do use the GUI.

221
00:12:43.180 --> 00:12:44.390
I know he's joking around about it.

222
00:12:44.390 --> 00:12:46.930
But we go back and
forth between using the GUI and

223
00:12:46.930 --> 00:12:49.510
terminal applications all
the time in doing this.

224
00:12:49.510 --> 00:12:54.410
You know so I just decided well I
was going that over on to the left

225
00:12:54.410 --> 00:12:56.917
hand side to make it easy for me.

226
00:12:56.917 --> 00:13:01.824
You also have down at the bottom in
the interface you can click on it and

227
00:13:01.824 --> 00:13:07.338
you can get this nice category view of
your applications too if you so choose.

228
00:13:07.338 --> 00:13:10.162
I really like it, the silky smooth,

229
00:13:10.162 --> 00:13:15.184
kind of really clean way they've
done the interface of this one.

230
00:13:15.184 --> 00:13:20.011
I could very easily do that right
there all day, the way things come up.

231
00:13:20.011 --> 00:13:25.360
[LAUGH] So you've got those ways
of accessing your applications.

232
00:13:25.360 --> 00:13:30.550
But then,
you look over here in the upper right.

233
00:13:30.550 --> 00:13:31.549
Some stuff you'll recognize.

234
00:13:31.549 --> 00:13:36.550
You can see your volume button, and your
power button, and all that good stuff.

235
00:13:36.550 --> 00:13:39.000
But one of the things I think is
really cool just to point out,

236
00:13:39.000 --> 00:13:41.910
is you have this little
camera icon up there.

237
00:13:41.910 --> 00:13:44.290
That camera icon, if you click on it.

238
00:13:44.290 --> 00:13:47.920
It actually allows you to go ahead and

239
00:13:49.180 --> 00:13:52.610
film the audio and
video of what's going on on screen.

240
00:13:52.610 --> 00:13:57.090
I mean think about this, instead of having
to download screen capture software and

241
00:13:57.090 --> 00:14:01.100
to show something that's happening,
if you're working with a client or you're

242
00:14:01.100 --> 00:14:05.460
using this as a forensics tool because
you can use it as a forensics tool.

243
00:14:05.460 --> 00:14:07.320
They have this built right in there and

244
00:14:07.320 --> 00:14:10.290
as part of product you can say
okay I want to show this process

245
00:14:10.290 --> 00:14:14.260
click hit start recording, and
it will just go through your process.

246
00:14:14.260 --> 00:14:16.777
And it will just keep saving that out and
you're ready to go.

247
00:14:16.777 --> 00:14:17.900
>> Wow.

248
00:14:17.900 --> 00:14:20.216
>> Yeah,
I think that's an incredibly nice feature.

249
00:14:20.216 --> 00:14:21.714
>> That's impressive yeah.

250
00:14:21.714 --> 00:14:26.550
>> So it's really helping you
out on that side of things.

251
00:14:26.550 --> 00:14:30.900
Some of the stuff that might be
a little confusing, initially,

252
00:14:30.900 --> 00:14:35.230
to you is when you hit this
down arrow either to log off or

253
00:14:35.230 --> 00:14:38.790
do your adjustments in here,
the system settings are down here.

254
00:14:38.790 --> 00:14:44.370
That's one of the ones that if
you noticed here [LAUGH] in our

255
00:14:44.370 --> 00:14:49.640
setup in here, it was like hold on, yeah
still getting used to it being over there.

256
00:14:49.640 --> 00:14:53.360
But, so there's our system settings,
so if you do get into this and

257
00:14:53.360 --> 00:14:55.940
you change your screen resolution or
pointing devices or

258
00:14:55.940 --> 00:14:58.980
anything like that,
then that's where that is.

259
00:14:58.980 --> 00:14:59.690
You know, so

260
00:14:59.690 --> 00:15:03.570
they have moved some stuff around in
there, which can be a little frustrating.

261
00:15:03.570 --> 00:15:05.627
So Just in case.

262
00:15:05.627 --> 00:15:07.034
>> The joys of a new interface.

263
00:15:07.034 --> 00:15:09.334
Usually, the benefits far
outweigh some of those,

264
00:15:09.334 --> 00:15:11.016
you just gotta redefine a few things.

265
00:15:11.016 --> 00:15:14.332
>> Yeah, I found, it's absolutely true,

266
00:15:14.332 --> 00:15:18.690
I found out that even though
this Interface look to be,

267
00:15:18.690 --> 00:15:22.886
when you get into it it's like,
they changed it.

268
00:15:22.886 --> 00:15:27.873
You weren't getting something like
the interface between an XP to Vista,

269
00:15:27.873 --> 00:15:30.337
or a 7 to 8, or anything like that.

270
00:15:30.337 --> 00:15:32.364
And I hear there's a new
version of Windows too, but

271
00:15:32.364 --> 00:15:33.756
I don't know what version that is.

272
00:15:33.756 --> 00:15:38.904
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's not like that, but

273
00:15:38.904 --> 00:15:44.890
it's sort of a huge shift where
something was radically different.

274
00:15:44.890 --> 00:15:46.230
You can get around this pretty easily.

275
00:15:46.230 --> 00:15:49.629
It was something that was like
well where is this, where is this?

276
00:15:49.629 --> 00:15:53.039
Settings honestly was probably
one of the ones that I was like

277
00:15:53.039 --> 00:15:56.212
there was a little icon here for
that, where did they put it?

278
00:15:56.212 --> 00:15:58.276
And it was like oh,
they stuck it over here.

279
00:15:58.276 --> 00:15:59.496
Okay.

280
00:15:59.496 --> 00:16:00.728
That's it.

281
00:16:00.728 --> 00:16:02.790
That was really the big thing.

282
00:16:04.040 --> 00:16:08.060
The other cool things to mention with
Cayley is that you can use this interface,

283
00:16:08.060 --> 00:16:09.840
you can use other interfaces, too.

284
00:16:09.840 --> 00:16:12.940
There are other interfaces
that are lighter weight.

285
00:16:12.940 --> 00:16:17.230
You can use KTE which is another one,
which looks more like the Windows type

286
00:16:17.230 --> 00:16:19.490
feel, kind of like
the start menu type deal.

287
00:16:19.490 --> 00:16:21.500
If you like that, they've got that.

288
00:16:21.500 --> 00:16:24.300
Then there's other ones that
are even more lightweight than that,

289
00:16:24.300 --> 00:16:27.620
if you want to go ahead and
use that type of deal.

290
00:16:27.620 --> 00:16:31.810
So you've got the option to mix and
match your interfaces to

291
00:16:31.810 --> 00:16:36.930
what you feel is going to be
the best benefit for you.

292
00:16:36.930 --> 00:16:37.430
>> Nice.
>> Yeah.

293
00:16:37.430 --> 00:16:39.640
Something I do want to point out though,

294
00:16:39.640 --> 00:16:42.418
this come at a price, obviously, right?

295
00:16:42.418 --> 00:16:46.660
[LAUGH] You are gonna pay for
it some way or the other.

296
00:16:46.660 --> 00:16:52.400
The system requirements are just
a little bit more with 2.0.

297
00:16:52.400 --> 00:16:56.490
That's if you use it stock out of the box,
and have it look like this here.

298
00:16:56.490 --> 00:16:59.310
If you're going to tweak it and
use a different interface,

299
00:16:59.310 --> 00:17:02.940
that will actually lower
the system requirements a bit.

300
00:17:02.940 --> 00:17:05.540
So you can really squeeze that down.

301
00:17:05.540 --> 00:17:09.240
So other than that,
the system requirements, at least for

302
00:17:09.240 --> 00:17:12.760
what we're talking about right now,
are gonna be mostly the same.

303
00:17:12.760 --> 00:17:19.170
So you don't expect to have this huge,
you know, titanic shift

304
00:17:19.170 --> 00:17:23.360
between one versus the other.

305
00:17:23.360 --> 00:17:27.250
But there are some differences, there
are some improved hardware support for

306
00:17:27.250 --> 00:17:31.330
some of the devices which is great,
improved support for

307
00:17:31.330 --> 00:17:33.780
different platforms which is great.

308
00:17:33.780 --> 00:17:37.130
So there are some benefits but overall.

309
00:17:37.130 --> 00:17:43.290
You've got the system requirements for
the stuff that we would generally use.

310
00:17:43.290 --> 00:17:45.620
They're a little different,
but they're not like oh,

311
00:17:45.620 --> 00:17:46.960
you better go get some new hardware.

312
00:17:46.960 --> 00:17:48.990
You can get some older
hardware to still run this.

313
00:17:48.990 --> 00:17:53.160
I could probably pick up a computer that',
you know, 5, 6 years old and

314
00:17:53.160 --> 00:17:56.970
still run this with very
little adjustment to it.

315
00:17:56.970 --> 00:17:57.940
Which is cool, you know.

316
00:17:57.940 --> 00:18:02.228
In fact I typically encourage people
to get in to pen testing, you know,

317
00:18:02.228 --> 00:18:04.000
don't get the newest stuff.

318
00:18:04.000 --> 00:18:06.050
That makes your job way too easy starting.

319
00:18:06.050 --> 00:18:09.310
It sounds like I'm being a jerk about it,
you know.

320
00:18:09.310 --> 00:18:14.700
It's like, no, if you use the old stuff,
now we can get that stuff cheaper.

321
00:18:14.700 --> 00:18:19.110
You can run just about a lot of
these tools on it just fine.

322
00:18:20.120 --> 00:18:24.900
And you'll learn how to,
your mind will expand in ways you

323
00:18:24.900 --> 00:18:28.840
hadn't expected when you don't
have the newer options available.

324
00:18:28.840 --> 00:18:31.760
[LAUGH] When you've gotta figure
out how to make something

325
00:18:31.760 --> 00:18:35.955
work with older technology, but
that's something for another time.

326
00:18:35.955 --> 00:18:40.950
[LAUGH] We've already come
pretty far as you can see right?

327
00:18:40.950 --> 00:18:45.760
There is quite a bit of differences
here but wait, there's more.

328
00:18:45.760 --> 00:18:47.280
>> There's more absolutely.

329
00:18:47.280 --> 00:18:49.940
So then we get different
versions I guess.-

330
00:18:49.940 --> 00:18:53.350
>> Yes, there are different versions.

331
00:18:53.350 --> 00:18:56.470
There's a different model
essentially between the two of them.

332
00:18:56.470 --> 00:18:59.860
There's this full version, which is
what you're seeing on screen here.

333
00:18:59.860 --> 00:19:03.260
This full version has all
the graphical benefits.

334
00:19:03.260 --> 00:19:07.550
You can see everything's all nice and
silky smooth when I hit it does the whole

335
00:19:07.550 --> 00:19:10.280
dealing cards and
everything for you type deal.

336
00:19:10.280 --> 00:19:15.590
But there's also a lite version,
which basically does

337
00:19:15.590 --> 00:19:20.000
away with all this graphical eye candy
bs if you want to look at it that way.

338
00:19:20.000 --> 00:19:23.920
It just says hey I'll get right down
to business it cuts down on all that

339
00:19:23.920 --> 00:19:25.380
graphical over head.

340
00:19:25.380 --> 00:19:29.660
And you've got just right clicks and stuff
like that to bring up shortcut menus and

341
00:19:29.660 --> 00:19:30.820
things like that.

342
00:19:30.820 --> 00:19:33.733
They designed those for
some of those older platforms, or

343
00:19:33.733 --> 00:19:36.894
platforms that just don't have
that extra [SOUND] behind them.

344
00:19:36.894 --> 00:19:44.000
Or in some cases, who knows, someone
may have a modern piece of hardware and

345
00:19:44.000 --> 00:19:48.885
decide, yeah it's a modern
piece of hardware, but

346
00:19:48.885 --> 00:19:53.326
I don't wanna waste all
this horsepower on just

347
00:19:53.326 --> 00:19:58.395
making something do these
fancy graphic effects.

348
00:19:58.395 --> 00:20:02.695
I want that being pushed over towards
how the actual work's being done.

349
00:20:02.695 --> 00:20:04.375
So they did create the lite version too.

350
00:20:04.375 --> 00:20:09.345
The lite version, if you notice it, I
believe it's about a third of the size of

351
00:20:09.345 --> 00:20:13.225
a download that the main Kali is.

352
00:20:13.225 --> 00:20:15.740
Kali itself is about three gigs.

353
00:20:15.740 --> 00:20:19.490
I think the other one's like .821 gigs.

354
00:20:19.490 --> 00:20:22.400
So, you can see there's
a substantial size difference.

355
00:20:22.400 --> 00:20:26.470
Mainly because they have stripped out a
lot of the stuff that makes it, you know,

356
00:20:26.470 --> 00:20:29.570
all nice and pretty and
maybe a few other things here and there.

357
00:20:29.570 --> 00:20:33.600
But it's still the same product.

358
00:20:33.600 --> 00:20:35.910
You can still do the same
pen testing stuff with it,

359
00:20:35.910 --> 00:20:38.230
which is what we're looking for.

360
00:20:38.230 --> 00:20:43.050
So you choose if you wanna have
the strip down, no bones about it,

361
00:20:43.050 --> 00:20:45.650
just shut your face and
get down to work one, or

362
00:20:45.650 --> 00:20:47.970
you wanna have something that
looks more pretty here, up to you.

363
00:20:49.200 --> 00:20:52.270
>> And then they've changed
the update model as well?

364
00:20:52.270 --> 00:20:55.060
>> Yeah, this is, this update model,

365
00:20:55.060 --> 00:20:59.900
I think this is probably the biggest
benefit you have with this, really.

366
00:20:59.900 --> 00:21:02.460
I mean this all well and
good seeing an interface,

367
00:21:02.460 --> 00:21:07.080
this is is absolutely all well and good,
but once I've shown you the interface and

368
00:21:07.080 --> 00:21:08.790
how it looks we'll explore that more.

369
00:21:08.790 --> 00:21:12.010
We can even get rid of that for
right now, we're done with that.

370
00:21:12.010 --> 00:21:15.620
Let's talk about this other
little piece that's going to be.

371
00:21:15.620 --> 00:21:18.500
That's gonna be a big interest to you.

372
00:21:18.500 --> 00:21:22.500
When you look at the update model in Kali,

373
00:21:23.640 --> 00:21:28.500
what they've done is in the past, you with
Kali or any of the versions of Linux,

374
00:21:28.500 --> 00:21:31.090
you would just go through and say,
well, I want to apply updates.

375
00:21:31.090 --> 00:21:33.290
And it would download, you know, updates.

376
00:21:33.290 --> 00:21:36.240
But if there were major updates,
you might have actually had to

377
00:21:36.240 --> 00:21:41.140
download some major stuff, or
you may have just had to grab it again.

378
00:21:41.140 --> 00:21:44.200
There were cases where you had to do that.

379
00:21:44.200 --> 00:21:48.150
Well, what they've done with this one
is they changed that model a bit.

380
00:21:48.150 --> 00:21:52.190
No longer do you have to
redownload a bunch of stuff or

381
00:21:52.190 --> 00:21:54.470
grab individual tools and
put them in there.

382
00:21:54.470 --> 00:21:58.560
What they've done is they've gone with
what they call this rolling update model.

383
00:21:58.560 --> 00:22:03.420
This rolling update model allows them
to slip stream stuff into the product

384
00:22:03.420 --> 00:22:08.060
a lot quicker so they can just say
hey we've made a change to something.

385
00:22:08.060 --> 00:22:11.180
We can just send it right on down
to you and it improves the product.

386
00:22:11.180 --> 00:22:14.730
That sounds great,
you know it sounds like well, it's great.

387
00:22:14.730 --> 00:22:18.950
But isn't that what, you know,
Windows and Microsoft has been doing.

388
00:22:18.950 --> 00:22:20.785
No you're completely wrong,
get out of my class.

389
00:22:20.785 --> 00:22:22.690
[LAUGHS] It's completely different.

390
00:22:24.200 --> 00:22:25.010
No, it is.

391
00:22:25.010 --> 00:22:26.340
If you just look at a dot level, yeah,

392
00:22:26.340 --> 00:22:30.390
it's what other vendors have been going,
with their stuff.

393
00:22:30.390 --> 00:22:33.180
Being able to slip stream stuff
in if you look at it that way.

394
00:22:33.180 --> 00:22:36.030
But there's something
else that goes with that.

395
00:22:36.030 --> 00:22:39.830
Is offensive security
the people that make Kali.

396
00:22:39.830 --> 00:22:45.200
They can actually slip stream
in new tools in there and

397
00:22:45.200 --> 00:22:48.820
updates tool much, much quicker
than you ever could do before.

398
00:22:48.820 --> 00:22:51.720
So you don't have to go search for
updates for individual tools.

399
00:22:51.720 --> 00:22:53.890
They can just start shooting
those things in there.

400
00:22:53.890 --> 00:22:56.600
If they want to put a new tool in there
for you, they can just shoot it right on

401
00:22:56.600 --> 00:22:59.390
down the line to you and
it will show up on your product, you know.

402
00:22:59.390 --> 00:23:03.870
So it means that you
can keep this product.

403
00:23:03.870 --> 00:23:06.400
Up to date much, much quicker and much,

404
00:23:06.400 --> 00:23:09.320
much more effectively than
you ever could before.

405
00:23:09.320 --> 00:23:13.780
Before you were gonna get notices of
updates and have to go through and do,

406
00:23:13.780 --> 00:23:16.300
the whole jazz that way.

407
00:23:16.300 --> 00:23:22.900
No, this way, you have the shift from
one to two, which did a big shift.

408
00:23:22.900 --> 00:23:27.140
But if they wanna add in more tools,
and make bigger changes to it,

409
00:23:27.140 --> 00:23:29.880
it's not like their going to have to
go from two to three just for that.

410
00:23:29.880 --> 00:23:32.570
I mean they will go from two to three at
some point, who knows when that will be,

411
00:23:32.570 --> 00:23:34.330
but they'll go from two
to three at some point.

412
00:23:35.590 --> 00:23:38.810
The benefit that they've done is,

413
00:23:38.810 --> 00:23:42.590
two is that it's not such a major thing
for them to have to do it just for

414
00:23:42.590 --> 00:23:45.940
the fact we want to included a bunch of
new stuff and change a bunch of things.

415
00:23:45.940 --> 00:23:49.270
They can do a lot of that buy
just slipping these updates in.

416
00:23:49.270 --> 00:23:51.210
Much more rapidly and

417
00:23:51.210 --> 00:23:54.220
much more effectively than they
ever could with the prior version.

418
00:23:54.220 --> 00:23:59.720
So it means you can effectively have a new
version, an updated version all the time.

419
00:23:59.720 --> 00:24:01.260
And it will check for those things.

420
00:24:01.260 --> 00:24:04.600
I believe it checks, I wanna say, I think
it's, don't quote me on it, but I think

421
00:24:04.600 --> 00:24:09.160
it's like four times a day it will check
for updates on it, just automatically.

422
00:24:09.160 --> 00:24:12.730
And so you should be ready to go, and
there's even buttons in there where,

423
00:24:12.730 --> 00:24:15.440
if you're really paranoid you
can click and say do a check for

424
00:24:15.440 --> 00:24:17.540
updates and it will check for you.

425
00:24:17.540 --> 00:24:21.980
And I've noticed they have
already put some, you know,

426
00:24:21.980 --> 00:24:22.870
updates and stuff like that.

427
00:24:22.870 --> 00:24:25.610
Not security updates, but
just updates saying, oh well

428
00:24:25.610 --> 00:24:29.390
we're gonna add in something here or tweak
this, or include something else here.

429
00:24:29.390 --> 00:24:34.000
You know, so that's a big, big thing.

430
00:24:34.000 --> 00:24:36.140
So really, really cool and

431
00:24:36.140 --> 00:24:40.660
exciting things that you have with
the improvements in the interface,

432
00:24:40.660 --> 00:24:44.590
with the improvements in the tools,
just being easier to get around.

433
00:24:44.590 --> 00:24:47.950
The broader hardware support and

434
00:24:47.950 --> 00:24:50.620
just a bunch of other things we have yet
to get into.

435
00:24:50.620 --> 00:24:58.120
It really makes Kali worth it to jump
over to, Jump from one over into 2 now.

436
00:24:58.120 --> 00:25:02.920
Like we said, you can use just about
everything you learned in 1 in 2,

437
00:25:02.920 --> 00:25:06.970
but we're going to build on top of that,
so

438
00:25:06.970 --> 00:25:11.630
we're not going to spend the same
length of time on 2 that we did on 1.

439
00:25:11.630 --> 00:25:14.870
We are going to introduce you to
some new stuff here along the way.

440
00:25:14.870 --> 00:25:16.530
Get you familiar with things so

441
00:25:16.530 --> 00:25:20.290
kinda get some excitement to get some
additional exploring on your own.

442
00:25:20.290 --> 00:25:21.850
>> Very good.
All right well Sean, I'll tell you what.

443
00:25:21.850 --> 00:25:22.550
A great episode.

444
00:25:22.550 --> 00:25:25.310
A lot of good information out as we move

445
00:25:25.310 --> 00:25:28.750
from previous versions
of Kali to Kali 2.0.

446
00:25:28.750 --> 00:25:30.390
A brand new interface.

447
00:25:30.390 --> 00:25:34.000
Probably easier to navigate around,
pretty update model.

448
00:25:34.000 --> 00:25:35.000
All kinds of good stuff.

449
00:25:35.000 --> 00:25:38.910
Looking forward to the rest of the show
as we cover some of those new features.

450
00:25:38.910 --> 00:25:41.040
But for now, we are out of time.

451
00:25:41.040 --> 00:25:44.040
So signing off for
ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

452
00:25:44.040 --> 00:25:45.100
>> And I am Sean Oriyano.

453
00:25:45.100 --> 00:25:46.140
>> And we'll see you tomorrow.

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike take a look at Kali Nethunter. They discuss the supported platforms for installing Nethunter. They also talk about some of the limitations of Kali Nethunter.
episodes.title: Kali Nethunter

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike demonstrate installing Kali 2.0. They talk about the different installation and upgrade options. Then they install Kali 2.0 in a virtual machine.
episodes.title: Installing and Upgrading Kali 2.0

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike take a look at the post installation tasks in Kali 2.0. They demonstrate adding users and customizing the interface. They also talk about adding proprietary drivers, and installing other tools.
episodes.title: Post-Installation Tasks

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike look at building a custom image for installing Kali Linux. They start by setting up the live-build system. Sean then describes the process of adding packages for your custom build.
episodes.title: Creating a Custom Kali Image

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Don look at running Kali Linux in forensics mode. They demonstrate how to launch Kali Linux in forensics mode. They also discuss the advantages of running Kali in forensics mode.
episodes.title: Forensics Mode

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike take a look at DNMAP. They talk about the reasons for using DNMAP. Then they configure DNMAP to do a distributed scan.
episodes.title: Footprinting with DNMAP

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike look at the process of cracking passwords. They start by looking at ways to generate a list of targets. Then they use Crunch to generate a wordlist for password cracking. They also look at the password cracking utility Medusa, examining the options for launching a password cracking attack.
episodes.title: Password Cracking

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike take a look at OpenVAS. They compare OpenVAS with other vulnerability scanners. Then they go through the initial configuration, run a scan, and look at the results.
episodes.title: Scanning with OpenVAS

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike look at two web vulnerability scanners, Skipfish and Vega. They start with Vega, scanning a couple of websites and analyzing the results. Next they contrast that with Skipfish, a command line utility.
episodes.title: Scanning with Skipfish and Vega

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Don look at Zed Attack Proxy, a web application vulnerability scanner. They use ZAP to scan a website and analyze the results. They look at the features in ZAP, and the different modules available to extend the functionality of ZAP.
episodes.title: Working with Zed Proxy

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike look at a tool new to Kali 2.0, Inguma.
episodes.title: Inguma

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike look at a tool called Responder.
episodes.title: MITM and Responder

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike look at the post-exploitation tool, Intersect. Intersect generates a python script that can be run on a compromised system to gather information. They demonstrate how to load different modules in Intersect. Then they generate a script with the loaded modules.
episodes.title: Post-Attack with Intersect

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike talk about the pros and cons of using iOS and Android
episodes.title: Mobile and Android Pen Testing

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike take a look at Kali Nethunter. They talk about the advantages of running Kali Nethunter vs a rooted stock Android OS. They compare two Nexus 7 devices, one running stock Android OS, the other one running Kali Nethunter.
episodes.title: Looking at Kali Nethunter

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike begin the process of installing Kali Nethunter. They discuss the various devices supported by Kali, and some of the pros and cons of each. They talk about the system requirements for installing Kali Nethunter. They demonstrate putting a Nexus 7 in developer mode and changing the USB connection to PTP in preparation for installation.
episodes.title: Installing Kali Nethunter

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike continue the process of installing Kali Nethunter on a Nexus 7. They demonstrate using the Nexus Root Toolkit. They use NRT to backup the device, install the necessary drivers, and unlock the bootloader. They also show how to restore a soft-bricked device using the flash stock and unroot option.
episodes.title: Installing Kali Nethunter Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike continue the process of installing Kali Nethunter on a Nexus 7. They start with a quick review of the prerequisites for installing Kali Nethunter. Then they demonstrate the Nethunter Installer, going through the steps to begin the installation process.
episodes.title: Installing Kali Nethunter Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike explore some post-installation tasks on Kali Nethunter.  These tasks include updating applications and configuring your Google account for access to Google Play. They also talk about installing additional tools and configuring them for first use. Then they go over some external accessories to use with Kali Nethunter, like an OTG cable, external wireless and bluetooth adapters, and cases.
episodes.title: Post-Installation Tasks

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike talk about the advantages of building your own Pwn Pad and Pwn Phone. They take a look at available hardware choices, including external adapters. They also go over what will be needed to build a Pwn Pad, including Pwn Pad 2014 Community Edition and a physical machine running Linux.
episodes.title: Pwn Pad and Pwn Phone

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike begin the process of creating a Pwn Pad on a Nexus 7. They look at setting up a Linux Ubuntu 12.4 machine with all of the tools needed to create a Pwn Pad. After downloading the Pwn Pad 2014 Community Edition, they begin the installation.
episodes.title: Creating Your Own Pwn Pad

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike perform post-installation tasks on a newly created Pwn Pad Community Edition 2014. They start by checking the Ubuntu system for errors during the installation process. Then they cover setting up the device for use, including updating applications and linking to Google Play.
episodes.title: Post-Installation Tasks

episodes.description: In this episode Sean and Mike explore some adapters that can be used with a Pwn Pad. They look at the TP-Link USB adapter as well as the SENA UD100 Industrial Bluetooth USB Adapter. The Pwn Pad is designed to work with these adapters, and extends the range and functionality of the Pwn Pad.
episodes.title: Pwn Pad Wifi & Bluetooth

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike look at some of the USB-based attacks that can be done with Kali Nethunter. They look at BadUSB MITM Attack which is a man-in-the-middle attack, as well as the HID Keyboard Attack which allows keystrokes to be sent from Kali Nethunter to the attack target.
episodes.title: USB Attacks with Nethunter

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike take a look at setting up Evil Access Point. This application allows you to create an access point to allow MITM attacks. They demonstrate setting up the application on both the Pwn Pad and Kali Nethunter.
episodes.title: Evil Access Point

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike demonstrate configuring a Pwn Pad and an application called SSL Strip. this application allows you to perform a MiTM attack by preventing the victim from setting up an SSL connection.
episodes.title: MiTM with SSL Strip
